name: Frank Darabont
trademark: Hawaiian shirts

name: Francis Ford Coppola
trademark: Often works with cinematographer Gordon Willis and producers Fred Roos and Gray Frederickson.

name: Christopher Nolan
trademark: Enormous visual scope and heavy emphasis on location and architecture

name: Sidney Lumet
trademark: Highly dialogue driven films, with a lot of speeches and dramatic verbal duels.

name: Steven Spielberg
trademark: He often shows performers staring, usually at something off-camera.

name: Peter Jackson
trademark: Has an interest in matricide (Derek is "born-again" in the ending of Bad Taste (1987), Sidney kills his wife and mother of his son in Meet the Feebles (1989), Lionel Cosgrove kills his mother in Braindead (1992), Pauline Rieper kills her mother in Heavenly Creatures (1994), and Patricia Ann Bradley kills her mother in The Frighteners (1996).

name: Quentin Tarantino
trademark: Recurring theme of honor among criminals

name: David Fincher
trademark: His films often center on people with poor social skills and few friends: The Narrator in Fight Club (1999), Mark Zuckerberg in The Social Network (2010) , Lisbeth Salander in The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011), Amy Dunne in Gone Girl (2014).

name: Robert Zemeckis
trademark: Often uses a scene in a restaurant/bar, with the main character starting a fight and then fleeing out into the street, where a complicated chase ensues (Back to the Future (1985), Who Framed Roger Rabbit (1988), Back to the Future Part II (1989), Back to the Future Part III (1990)).

name: Irvin Kershner
trademark: Fills up the movie frame with the characters' faces

name: Lana Wachowski
trademark: Frequently casts Joe Pantoliano and Hugo Weaving

name: Martin Scorsese
trademark: Often when the formal end-credits song is over before the credit sequence, the remaining minute or so will have atmospheric sound footage pertaining to the movie. For instance, The Age of Innocence (1993) had sounds of a horse-drawn carriage; The Last Waltz (1978) had the Winterland audience filing out as "Greensleeves" was played on the organ; Gangs of New York (2002) had modern-day New York ...

name: Milos Forman
trademark: Bio-pics about unlovable celebrities (Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Larry Flynt, Andy Kaufman)

name: Frank Capra
trademark: Often cast James Stewart, Gary Cooper, and Cary Grant

name: Jonathan Demme
trademark: Characters looking directly into the camera

name: George Lucas
trademark: His films usually feature a battle scene which takes place around a large shaft  or pit.

name: Luc Besson
trademark: Typically, during the opening-titles, the camera moves towards something important for the movie, but looks down until the important part of credits was shown, then swings up, now looking at a place or character.

name: Roger Allers
trademark: No info

name: Charles Chaplin
trademark: Walking with a waddle

name: Bryan Singer
trademark: Recurring theme of alienation in his films

name: Roman Polanski
trademark: By the end of his films, the protagonist often meets an uncertain, melancholic future (The Ninth Gate (1999), The Ghost Writer (2010), Rosemary's Baby (1968), Chinatown (1974) and Macbeth (1971)).

name: James Cameron
trademark: His films frequently feature scenes filmed in deep blues

name: Ridley Scott
trademark: He often utilizes a light blue tint that contrasts black silhouettes, e.g. G.I. Jane (1997), Gladiator (2000), Black Hawk Down (2001), Matchstick Men (2003) and Kingdom of Heaven (2005).

name: Tony Kaye
trademark: Use of flashbacks and cutaways

name: Alfred Hitchcock
trademark: Always formally dressed, wearing a suit on film sets

name: Damien Chazelle
trademark: His films often revolve heavily around jazz music

name: Sergio Leone
trademark: Characters in his films frequently play a musical device, with the music  appearing also in the composer's score (Indio's watch chimes in For a Few Dollars More (1965), Harmonica's harmonica in Once Upon a Time in the West (1968)).

name: Thomas Kail
trademark: No info

name: Michael Curtiz
trademark: No info

name: Stanley Kubrick
trademark: Starting with Lolita (1962), each film has at least one scene in a bathroom.

name: Todd Phillips
trademark: Famous actors in a cameo roles

name: Billy Wilder
trademark: Films feature a sharp wit and characters who frequently try to change their identity.

name: Anthony Russo
trademark: No info

name: Andrew Stanton
trademark: Uses music by Thomas Newman

name: Bob Persichetti
trademark: No info

name: Lee Unkrich
trademark: No info

name: Mel Gibson
trademark: Often plays angry or deranged characters

name: Sam Mendes
trademark: Often works with 'Daniel Craig'.

name: John Lasseter
trademark: Hawaiian shirts or shirts with colorful designs

name: Gus Van Sant
trademark: Frequently casts Matt Dillon, Keanu Reeves, Grace Zabriskie, Matt Damon and James Remar

name: Florian Zeller
trademark: No info

name: Richard Marquand
trademark: No info

name: Darren Aronofsky
trademark: Lengthy over-the-shoulder shots

name: Michel Gondry
trademark: Surreal settings and visual effects

name: Stanley Donen
trademark: No info

name: Orson Welles
trademark: Long takes

name: Guy Ritchie
trademark: Numerous plot threads that intersect and assist in each other's payoffs

name: Brian De Palma
trademark: Doppelgangers (or evil twins), and femme fatales appear frequently in DePalma's films.

name: George Roy Hill
trademark: The use of Jump cuts in action sequences

name: David Lean
trademark: The horizon is almost always kept in view

name: Robert Mulligan
trademark: No info

name: Pete Docter
trademark: His films often feature the main character protecting a child in some way.

name: Michael Mann
trademark: Often films pivotal or imporant scenes at night, such as the end shootout at the airport in Heat (1995), Collateral (2004) and the end shootout in the boat yard, as well as others, in Miami Vice (2006).

name: Peter Farrelly
trademark: Irreverent and politically incorrect humor. Often using extreme, risque gross-out gags, and broad stereotypes.

name: Curtis Hanson
trademark: Characters in his films often reference or are seen watching movies from the Golden Age of cinema.

name: John McTiernan
trademark: Very active movement of camera

name: Terry Gilliam
trademark: Heavy use of wide angle lenses

name: Stanley Kramer
trademark: No info

name: Joseph L. Mankiewicz
trademark: No info

name: Clint Eastwood
trademark: His films reflect upon real-life stories

name: John Sturges
trademark: Predominantly male ensemble casts.

name: Ron Howard
trademark: Known for making films based on real-life events

name: Ernst Lubitsch
trademark: In most of his comedies, he took up serious subjects and spiced them with elegance, sophistication, cynicism and witty lines - It became known as "the Lubitsch Touch."

name: John Huston
trademark: Often cast his daughter Anjelica Huston

name: Paul Thomas Anderson
trademark: Frequently uses extended takes

name: Sergio Pablos
trademark: No info

name: Martin McDonagh
trademark: Often casts Zeljko Ivanek, Colin Farrell, Woody Harrelson, Abbie Cornish and Sam Rockwell

name: James McTeigue
trademark: No info

name: David Lynch
trademark: Constant references to dreams as a way of connecting the plot and twists in his  films.

name: Gavin O'Connor
trademark: Family relationships are a major theme of his works

name: John Carpenter
trademark: [Cinematography] Uses minimalist cinematography and lighting. Tries to make empty spaces look full, and full spaces look empty. Shoots all of his movies in Panavision (2.35:1 ratio with anamorphic lenses). The exceptions are Dark Star (1974) and all of his TV work.

name: Ethan Coen
trademark: A tense situation in a moving car. E.g. Fargo (1996), The Big Lebowski (1998), Burn After Reading (2008) and Blood Simple (1984).

name: Victor Fleming
trademark: No info

name: M. Night Shyamalan
trademark: Car crashes play pivotal roles in all his films: Cole reveals his gift to his mother  during a traffic jam in The Sixth Sense (1999), David "loses" his football  abilities in a car accident in Unbreakable (2000), and Graham's wife dies  in a bizarre car accident in Signs (2002).

name: Danny Boyle
trademark: Frequently works with screenwriter 'John Hodge'

name: Peter Weir
trademark: His films often revolve around the individual standing up to conformity.

name: Moustapha Akkad
trademark: Is known as the grandfather of the Halloween movies

name: Elia Kazan
trademark: Frequently cast Marlon Brando and Karl Malden

name: Carol Reed
trademark: Often cast Trevor Howard

name: Jim Sheridan
trademark: Two young daughters in the family (In America, Brothers, Dream House)

name: Adam Elliot
trademark: No info

name: Joel Coen
trademark: References to the films of Stanley Kubrick

name: Lenny Abrahamson
trademark: No info

name: Michael Cimino
trademark: Abrupt flash-forwards (The Deer Hunter (1978), Heaven's Gate (1980), Year of the Dragon (1985))

name: Richard Linklater
trademark: Likable easy-going lead characters

name: Wes Anderson
trademark: Makes obsessive and comedic use of rostrum camera insert shots, foregrounding the minutiae of books and other documents.

name: Denis Villeneuve
trademark: Frequently uses a song by Radiohead in his films.

name: James Mangold
trademark: Characters become unlikely couples

name: Dean DeBlois
trademark: Often works with Chris Sanders

name: Michael Powell
trademark: No info

name: Lasse Hallström
trademark: No info

name: Steve McQueen
trademark: Dialogue scenes shot in a single take or a series of long takes

name: David Yates
trademark: Use of hand-held camera

name: Raoul Walsh
trademark: Although he directed in numerous "manly" genres, he is principally remembered as a master of crime dramas

name: William Wyler
trademark: Known for his rich, honest exploration of people and human behavior, regardless of the scale of the film

name: Stuart Rosenberg
trademark: No info

name: George Miller
trademark: His versatility with the genres and subject matters of the films he directs

name: Tomm Moore
trademark: The main protagonists in his films are kids who have a young friend or sibling with magic abilities.

name: Rob Reiner
trademark: Often includes references to his previous films

name: Giuseppe Tornatore
trademark: No info

name: Sean Penn
trademark: Frequently plays unsympathetic and cruel characters with a hidden moral center

name: Oliver Stone
trademark: Non-linear storytelling and flashback structure.

name: Zack Snyder
trademark: Extreme attention to detail in recreating comic book panels

name: Terry Jones
trademark: Dark brown hair and eyes, short stocky build

name: F.W. Murnau
trademark: Towering height

name: John Ford
trademark: Rarely shot a scene with more than two takes

name: Terry George
trademark: No info

name: Tom McCarthy
trademark: Low-key films about disparate people who become unusual surrogate families

name: Wim Wenders
trademark: Self-reflection of the filmmaking and image-making process.

name: John G. Avildsen
trademark: Underdog films complete with realistic character development and montage sequences

name: Robert Aldrich
trademark: Extreme and often selfish leading characters

name: Peter Bogdanovich
trademark: Always seen wearing a neck scarf

name: Tate Taylor
trademark: Frequently casts Octavia Spencer and Allison Janney.

name: Alan Parker
trademark: Films based on true stories

name: Garth Davis
trademark: Frequently works with Rooney Mara

name: Martin Brest
trademark: No info

name: Ron Clements
trademark: Beard

name: Lewis Milestone
trademark: No info

name: James Gunn
trademark: Nearly always casts Nathan Fillion, Elizabeth Banks, Gregg Henry, Michael Rooker, Lloyd Kaufman, brother Sean Gunn and Rob Zombie in his movies. His dog Wesley Von Spears often get the roles as well

name: Alexander Mackendrick
trademark: No info

name: Gore Verbinski
trademark: Wide detailed shots

name: Richard Attenborough
trademark: Frequently cast Anthony Hopkins

name: Brad Bird
trademark: Rarely using big stars, the voice actors in his films are often character actors or unprofessional and unknown voice talents

name: William Friedkin
trademark: Infamous for his volatile, provocative behavior on film sets

name: Lars von Trier
trademark: Shoots digitally, encorporating imperfect hand-held camera movements that go in and out of focus.

name: Franklin J. Schaffner
trademark: Frequently directed films based off books.

name: Robert Wise
trademark: No info

name: Gary Trousdale
trademark: Frequently directs with Kirk Wise

name: Harold Ramis
trademark: Deep resonant voice

name: Morten Tyldum
trademark: No info

name: Richard Kelly
trademark: Frequently casts Beth Grant, Holmes Osborne, and Lisa K. Wyatt

name: Otto Preminger
trademark: Fluid camera movements and long takes

name: Mel Brooks
trademark: All of his movies feature a wacky song-and-dance number

name: Kevin Costner
trademark: Frequently appears in Westerns

name: Byron Howard
trademark: Protagonists are considered enemies of each other (cat and dog in Bolt; princess and thief in Tangled, fox and rabbit in Zootopia)

name: Paul Greengrass
trademark: Stories based on real-life events.

name: Barry Levinson
trademark: Films set in his home town of in Baltimore, Maryland: Diner (1982), Tin Men (1987), Avalon (1990) and Liberty Heights (1999).

name: Joss Whedon
trademark: Often gives his characters names that are later revealed to be their last names and/or based on an unusual abbreviation for their full name. For example: only after the character Oz had already left Buffy the Vampire Slayer (1997) did the show reveal that "Oz" was an abbreviation of his full name, Daniel Osbourne; on "Angel," they did not clarify that Doyle was actually the character's last name ...

name: Charles Laughton
trademark: Often played arrogant characters, typecast for these roles early in his career by playing King Henry VIII and Captain Bligh

name: Robert Hamer
trademark: No info

name: Jacques Tourneur
trademark: No info

name: Gabriele Muccino
trademark: Character named Ristuccia.

name: Mike Nichols
trademark: Often includes extremely long starting and/or ending shots taken from high in the air, for example Working Girl (1988) and Angels in America (2003).

name: Edward Zwick
trademark: Frequently casts Denzel Washington

name: Spike Jonze
trademark: Frequently uses music from Karen O and the Arcade Fire

name: Norman Jewison
trademark: No info

name: Richard Brooks
trademark: No info

name: Tom Hooper
trademark: Distinctive visual style involving dutch angles, hand-held cameras, and putting actors in the far side of a shot

name: Howard Hawks
trademark: In most of his films there is at least one scene that involves his characters singing and playing instruments.

name: Billy Bob Thornton
trademark: Houston Colt 45's hat

name: Woody Allen
trademark: His films are almost all set in New York City
